sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change in a reaction
message_1: Calculate the Gibbs free energy change for the combustion of methane (CH4) at 298 K and 1 atm of pressure when 1 mole of methane is burned completely. Standard molar enthalpy of combustion and standard molar entropy of methane are -890.4 kJ/mol and 186.2 J/K•mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for the combustion of methane, we can use the following equation:

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS

where ΔH is the change in enthalpy, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and ΔS is the change in entropy.

Given that the standard molar enthalpy of combustion (ΔH) for methane is -890.4 kJ/mol, the temperature (T) is 298 K, and the standard molar entropy (ΔS) is 186.2 J/K•mol, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔG = (-890.4 kJ/mol) - (298 K)(186.2 J/K•mol)

First, we need to convert the entropy from J/K•mol to kJ/K•mol:

186.2 J/K•mol * (1 kJ / 1000 J) = 0.1862 kJ/K•mol

Now, we can plug this value back into the equation:

ΔG = (-890.4 kJ/mol) - (298 K)(0.1862 kJ/K•mol)

ΔG = (-890.4 kJ/mol) - (55.6 kJ/mol)

ΔG = -946 kJ/mol

Therefore, the Gibbs free energy change for the combustion of 1 mole of methane at 298 K and 1 atm of pressure is approximately -946 kJ/mol.
